headline: Air Lease Is Going Private. Why Boeing Stock Is Up.
summary: A big aircraft lessor is going private, a modest signal of confidence in the outlook for the aviation industry.  Tuesday,  Air Lease  said it had agreed to be acquired by investors including Sumitomo, SMBC Aviation Capital, investment vehicles affiliated with  Apollo  and  Brookfield  Shareholders are getting $65 per share in cash.  Air Lease stock was up 6.6% in midday trading, at $64.17, while the  and  were down 1.4% and 1.1%, respectively.

Air Lease stock was up 6.6% in midday trading, at $64.17, while the  and  were down 1.4% and 1.1%, respectively.

headline: Top economist Torsten Slok warns of an ‘inflation mountain’ in a potential repeat of the ’70s
summary: “The risks are rising that we could see another ‘inflation mountain’ emerge over the coming months,” Apollo Global’s chief economist said.

headline: Apollo Completes Acquisition of Bridge Investment Group
summary: NEW YORK and SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 02, 2025 (GLOBE NEWSWIRE) -- Apollo (NYSE: APO) and Bridge Investment Group Holdings Inc. (“Bridge”) today announced that Apollo has completed the previously announced acquisition of Bridge in an all-stock transaction. As a platform company within Apollo’s asset management business, Bridge will retain its existing brand, management and investment teams and dedicated capital formation team. headline: Air Lease Agrees To $7.4 Billion Takeover By Sumitomo-Backed Consortium, Stock Soars
summary: Air Lease Corp. (NYSE:AL) shares climbed after the aircraft lessor said it will be acquired by a newly formed Dublin-based holding company backed by Sumitomo Corp. (OTC:SSUMY), SMBC Aviation Capital Ltd., and investment funds tied to Apollo Global Management (NYSE:APO) and Brookfield (NYSE:BN). The cash deal values the aircraft lessor at $7.4 billion, or $28.2 billion including debt. Shareholders will receive $65 per share in cash, a 7% premium over Air Lease’s record-high closing price and a 31

headline: Apollo Global planning $5 billion sports fund, FT reports
summary: Apollo will hire new employees to lead the strategy, which will focus on lending to sports leagues and teams, and buying stakes in clubs, the newspaper said, citing unidentified sources.  Apollo declined to comment on the FT report.

headline: Apollo Names Yasuo Kashiwagi Head of Japan
summary: Seasoned executive to advance firm’s role as a leading provider of flexible private capital solutions to the Japan marketNEW YORK, Sept. 01, 2025 (GLOBE NEWSWIRE) -- Apollo (NYSE: APO) today announced that Yasuo Kashiwagi has joined the firm as Head of Japan, overseeing the firm’s integrated strategy and local partnerships in Japan, including local operations across asset management, capital solutions, wealth and retirement solutions.
